<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;3.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Legal Proceedings </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of
September&nbsp;26, 2009, the end of the annual period covered by this report, the Company was subject to the various legal proceedings and claims discussed below, as well as certain other legal proceedings and claims that have not been fully
resolved and that have arisen in the ordinary course of business. In the opinion of management, the Company does not have a potential liability related to any current legal proceedings and claims that would individually or in the aggregate
materially adversely affect its financial condition or operating results. However, the results of legal proceedings cannot be predicted with certainty. Should the Company fail to prevail in any of these legal matters or should several of these legal
matters be resolved against the Company in the same reporting period, the operating results of a particular reporting period could be materially adversely affected. The Company settled certain matters during the fourth quarter of 2009 that did not
individually or in the aggregate have a material impact on the Company&#146;s financial condition and results of operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Bader v. Anderson, et al. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this purported shareholder derivative action against the Company and
each of its then current executive officers and members of its Board of Directors on May&nbsp;19, 2005 in Santa Clara County Superior Court asserting claims for breach of fiduciary duty, material misstatements and omissions and violations of
California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition). The complaint alleged that the Company&#146;s March&nbsp;14, 2005, proxy statement was false and misleading for failure to disclose certain information relating to the
Apple Computer, Inc. Performance Bonus Plan, which was approved by shareholders at the annual meeting held on April&nbsp;21, 2005. Plaintiff, who ostensibly brought suit on the Company&#146;s behalf, made no demand on the Board of Directors and
alleged that such demand was excused. The complaint sought injunctive and other relief for purported injury to the Company. On July&nbsp;27, 2005, plaintiff filed an amended complaint alleging that, in addition to the purported derivative claims,
adoption of the bonus plan and distribution of the proxy statement describing that plan also inflicted injury on her directly as an individual shareholder. On January&nbsp;10, 2006, the Court sustained defendants&#146; demurrer to the amended
complaint, with leave to amend. Plaintiff filed a second amended complaint on February&nbsp;7, 2006, and the Company filed a demurrer. After a hearing on June&nbsp;13, 2006, the Court sustained the demurrer without leave to amend as to the
non-director officers and with leave to amend as to the directors. On July&nbsp;24, 2006, plaintiff filed a third amended complaint, which purported to bring claims derivatively as well as directly on behalf of a class of common stockholders who
have been or will be harmed by virtue of the allegedly misleading proxy statement. In addition to reasserting prior causes of action, the third amended complaint included a claim that the Company violated the terms of the plan, and a claim for waste
related to restricted stock unit grants to certain officers in 2003 and 2004 and an option grant to the Company&#146;s CEO in January 2000. The Company filed a demurrer to the third amended complaint. On January&nbsp;30, 2007, the Court sustained
the Company&#146;s demurrer with leave to amend. On May&nbsp;8, 2007, plaintiff filed a fourth amended complaint. The Company filed a demurrer to the fourth amended complaint, which the Court sustained, without leave to amend, on October&nbsp;12,
2007. On October&nbsp;25, 2007, the Court entered a final judgment in favor of defendant and ordered the case dismissed with prejudice. On November&nbsp;26, 2007, plaintiff filed a notice of appeal. A hearing on plaintiff&#146;s appeal is scheduled
for October&nbsp;29, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Birdsong v. Apple Computer, Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This action alleges that the Company&#146;s iPod music players, and the ear bud headphones sold with them, are inherently defective in design and are sold without adequate warnings
concerning the risk of noise-induced hearing loss by iPod users. The Birdsong action was initially filed on January&nbsp;30, 2006 in the United States District Court for the Western District of Louisiana asserting Louisiana causes of action on
behalf of a purported Louisiana class of iPod purchasers. A similar action<I> (Patterson v. Apple Computer, Inc.)</I> was filed on January&nbsp;31, 2006 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California asserting California
causes of action on behalf of a purported class of all iPod purchasers within the four-year period before January&nbsp;31, 2006. The Birdsong action was transferred to the Northern District of California, and the Patterson action was dismissed. An
amended complaint was subsequently filed in Birdsong, dropping the Louisiana law-based claims and adding California law-based claims equivalent to those in Patterson. After the Company filed a motion to
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">25 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
dismiss on November&nbsp;3, 2006, plaintiffs agreed not to oppose the motion and filed a second amended complaint on January&nbsp;16, 2007. That complaint alleges California law-based claims for
breaches of implied and express warranties, violations of California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false advertising), the Consumer Legal Remedies
Act and negligent misrepresentation on behalf of a putative nationwide class and a Louisiana law-based claim for redhibition for a Louisiana sub-class. On March&nbsp;1, 2007, the Company filed a motion to dismiss the California law-based claims,
which was heard on June&nbsp;4, 2007. On December&nbsp;14, 2007, the Court issued an order granting the Company&#146;s motion, with leave to amend the complaint. On January&nbsp;11, 2008, plaintiffs filed a third amended complaint, which seeks
restitution, injunctive relief, unspecified damages and attorneys&#146; fees. On February&nbsp;15, 2008, the Company filed a motion to dismiss the third amended complaint. On June&nbsp;16, 2008, the Court granted the Company&#146;s motion to dismiss
the third amended complaint with prejudice. On July&nbsp;11, 2008, plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal. A hearing on plaintiffs&#146; appeal took place on October&nbsp;8, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A similar complaint,<I> Royer-Brennan v. Apple Computer, Inc. and Apple Canada, Inc.,</I> was filed in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on February&nbsp;1, 2006, seeking authorization to
institute a class action on behalf of iPod purchasers in Quebec. Plaintiffs filed a motion to amend their complaint to add a minor plaintiff and claims regarding alleged risks of hearing loss to young people. The hearing on the motion to amend took
place on April&nbsp;24, 2009, and the Court denied plaintiffs&#146; motion with leave to resubmit it. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Branning et al. v.
Apple Computer, Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiffs originally filed this purported class action in San Francisco County Superior Court on
February&nbsp;17, 2005. The initial complaint alleged violations of California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition) and violation of the Consumer Legal Remedies Act regarding a variety of purportedly unfair and
unlawful conduct including but not limited to allegedly selling used computers as new and failing to honor warranties. Plaintiffs also brought causes of action for misappropriation of trade secrets, breach of contract and violation of the
Song-Beverly Consumer Warranty Act. Plaintiffs requested unspecified damages and other relief. On May&nbsp;2, 2005, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint adding two new named plaintiffs and three new causes of action including a claim for treble
damages under the Cartwright Act (California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;16700 et seq.) and a claim for false advertising. On May&nbsp;9, 2005, the Court granted the Company&#146;s motion to transfer the case to Santa Clara County
Superior Court. The Company filed a demurrer to the amended complaint, which the Court sustained in its entirety on November&nbsp;10, 2005. The Court granted plaintiffs leave to amend and they filed an amended complaint on December&nbsp;29, 2005.
Plaintiffs&#146; amended complaint added three plaintiffs and alleged many of the same factual claims as the previous complaints, such as alleged selling of used equipment as new, alleged failure to honor warranties and service contracts for the
consumer plaintiffs, and alleged fraud related to the opening of the Apple retail stores. Plaintiffs continued to assert causes of action for unfair competition (&#167;17200), violations of the Consumer Legal Remedies Act, breach of contract,
misappropriation of trade secrets, violations of the Cartwright Act, and alleged new causes of action for fraud, conversion, and breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. The Company filed a demurrer to the amended complaint on
January&nbsp;31, 2006, which the Court sustained on March&nbsp;3, 2006 on sixteen of seventeen causes of action. Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint adding one new plaintiff. The Company filed a demurrer, which was granted in part on
September&nbsp;9, 2006. Plaintiffs filed a further amended complaint on September&nbsp;21, 2006. On October&nbsp;2, 2006, the Company filed an answer denying all allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. On November&nbsp;30, 2007, the
Company filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings, which the Court denied. Plaintiffs filed a Fifth Amended Complaint on March&nbsp;19, 2008 and a Corrected Fifth Amended Complaint on April&nbsp;1, 2008. The Company filed an answer to the
Corrected Fifth Amended Complaint on April&nbsp;18, 2008. The Company filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings for an order dismissing plaintiffs&#146; fraud claim based upon the statute of limitations, which was granted by the Court on
June&nbsp;24, 2008, with leave to amend. Plaintiffs filed a Sixth Amended Complaint on July&nbsp;14, 2008 and a Seventh Amended Complaint on August&nbsp;22, 2008, adding three new reseller plaintiffs. On August&nbsp;22, 2008, plaintiffs also filed a
motion to certify the consumer class. On September&nbsp;22, 2008, the Company filed its answer to the consumer-related claims denying all allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses, and also filed a
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">26 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
demurrer to the new reseller claims, which the Court heard on January&nbsp;30, 2009. The Court sustained the demurrer as to all plaintiffs except one, with leave to amend. Plaintiffs filed an
Eighth Amended Complaint further amending the reseller claims on February&nbsp;24, 2009, and on March&nbsp;26, 2009, the Company filed a demurrer which was overruled, and a motion to strike which was denied. The Company filed motions for summary
adjudication for certain claims of two named plaintiffs, which the Court granted on November&nbsp;10, 2008. Plaintiffs petitioned the Court of Appeal for a writ of certiorari from the summary adjudication ruling and a motion to stay the class
certification hearing, which the Court of Appeal denied on December&nbsp;17, 2008. On December&nbsp;19, 2008, the Court held a hearing on plaintiffs&#146; class certification motion. The Court requested further briefing and an additional hearing,
which did not take place because on February&nbsp;23, 2009, Hon. Jamie A. Jacobs-May disqualified herself from the case. The Company filed a petition for a writ of mandate from this order, which the Court of Appeal denied on May&nbsp;19, 2009. The
case has been reassigned to Hon. Joseph H. Huber. The class certification hearing on the consumer-related claims took place on July&nbsp;14, 2009. The Company has filed two additional motions for summary adjudication as to all of the named
plaintiffs&#146; claims. The Company has also filed a motion to sever the consumer class and the reseller class for the purpose of trial. Plaintiffs&#146; motion for class certification of the reseller class is due November&nbsp;16, 2009.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Harvey v. Apple Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this action on August&nbsp;6, 2007 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Marshall Division, alleging infringement by the Company of U.S. Patent
No.&nbsp;6,753,671 entitled &#147;Recharger for use with a portable electronic device and which includes a proximally located light emitting device&#148; and U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,762,584 entitled &#147;Recharger for use with a portable electronic
device and which includes a connector terminus for communicating with rechargeable batteries contained within the device.&#148; The complaint seeks unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed an answer on October&nbsp;12, 2007 denying
all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The Company also asserted counterclaims for declaratory judgment of non-infringement and invalidity. On April&nbsp;7, 2008, plaintiff filed an amended complaint further alleging
infringement of the reissue patent of U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,753,671. On April&nbsp;28, 2008, the Company filed an answer denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The Company also asserted counterclaims for
declaratory judgment of non-infringement and invalidity. The Markman hearing is set for October&nbsp;28, 2009, and trial is scheduled for April&nbsp;5, 2010. On February&nbsp;3, 2009, the Court stayed the proceedings pending the U.S. Patent and
Trademark Office&#146;s allowance of the &#145;671 reissue patent. On July&nbsp;7, 2009, the Company filed a motion to transfer the case to the Northern District of California. On September&nbsp;19, 2009, the Company filed a motion to vacate the
Markman hearing set for October&nbsp;28, 2009, given the still pending reissue proceeding regarding U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,753,671. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Honeywell International,&nbsp;Inc., et al.&nbsp;v. Apple Computer,&nbsp;Inc., et al. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiffs Honeywell
International,&nbsp;Inc. and Honeywell Intellectual Properties,&nbsp;Inc. filed this action on October&nbsp;6, 2004 in the United States District Court in Delaware alleging infringement by the Company and other defendants of U.S. Patent
No.&nbsp;5,280,371 entitled &#147;Directional Diffuser for a Liquid Crystal Display.&#148; Plaintiffs seek unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed an answer on December&nbsp;21, 2004 denying all material allegations and asserting
numerous affirmative defenses. The Company has tendered the case to several liquid crystal display manufacturer suppliers. On May&nbsp;18, 2005 the Court stayed the case against the Company and the other non-manufacturer defendants. Plaintiffs filed
an amended complaint on November&nbsp;7, 2005 adding additional defendants and expanding the scope of the accused products. The Company&#146;s response to the amended complaint is not yet due. On April&nbsp;2, 2008, the Court lifted the stay for the
purpose of determining whether the liquid crystal display manufacturer suppliers used by the Company and certain other defendants are licensed under the &#145;371 patent. On October&nbsp;31, 2008, the Company filed a motion for summary judgment of
non-infringement based on the contention that its suppliers are licensed under the &#145;371 patent. A hearing on the motion has been postponed and has not been rescheduled. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">27 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>In re Apple iPod Nano Products Liability Litigation (formerly Wimmer v. Apple Computer,
Inc.; Moschella, et al., v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Calado, et al. v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Kahan, et al., v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Jennings, et al., v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Rappel v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Mayo v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Valencia v.
Apple Computer, Inc.; Williamson v. Apple Computer, Inc.; Sioson v. Apple Computer, Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Beginning on October&nbsp;19,
2005, eight complaints were filed in various United States District Courts and two complaints were filed in California State Court alleging that the Company&#146;s iPod nano was defectively designed so that it scratches excessively during normal
use, rendering the screen unreadable. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The federal actions were coordinated in the United States District Court for the
Northern District of California and assigned to the Hon. Ronald Whyte pursuant to an April&nbsp;17, 2006 order of the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation. Plaintiffs filed a First Consolidated and Amended Master Complaint on
September&nbsp;21, 2006, alleging violations of California and other states&#146; consumer protection and warranty laws and claiming unjust enrichment. The Master Complaint alleges two putative plaintiff classes: (1)&nbsp;all U.S. residents
(excluding California residents) who purchased an iPod nano that was not manufactured or designed using processes necessary to ensure normal resistance to scratching of the screen; and (2)&nbsp;all iPod nano purchasers other than U.S. residents who
purchased an iPod nano that was not manufactured or designed using processes necessary to ensure normal resistance to scratching of the screen. The Company answered the Master Complaint on November&nbsp;20, 2006. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The two California State Court actions were coordinated on May&nbsp;4, 2006, and assigned to the Hon. Carl West in Los Angeles County
Superior Court. Plaintiffs filed a Consolidated Amended Class Action Complaint on June&nbsp;8, 2006, alleging violations of California state consumer protection, unfair competition, false advertising and warranty laws and claiming unjust enrichment.
The Consolidated Complaint alleges a putative plaintiff class of all California residents who own an iPod nano containing a manufacturing defect that results in the nano being susceptible to excessive scratching. The Company answered the
Consolidated Amended Complaint on October&nbsp;6, 2006. The parties have reached a settlement and on April&nbsp;28, 2009, the Court granted final approval of the settlement. On May&nbsp;21, 2009, an objector filed a notice of appeal. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Individual Networks, LLC v. Apple, Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this action against the Company on April&nbsp;24, 2007 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Marshall Division, alleging infringement of U.S. Patent
No.&nbsp;7,117,516, entitled &#147;Method and System for Providing a Customized Media List.&#148; Plaintiff alleges certain features of the iTunes store infringe the patent. The complaint seeks unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed
an answer on July&nbsp;2, 2007, denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The Company also asserted counterclaims for declaratory judgment of non-infringement and invalidity, as well as a counterclaim against
Individual Networks LLC for infringement of U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;5,724,567. The trial is scheduled for November&nbsp;9, 2009. The Company has filed a petition with the United States Patent and Trademark Office requesting reexamination of U.S. Patent
No.&nbsp;7,117,516. The Markman hearing took place on October&nbsp;8, 2008, and the Court issued its Markman ruling on January&nbsp;12, 2009. The Company filed a motion for summary judgment of inequitable conduct on April&nbsp;10, 2009, and filed
motions for summary judgment of invalidity and lack of written description on April&nbsp;30, 2009. The Company has also filed a motion to exclude portions of plaintiff&#146;s expert&#146;s report and testimony regarding damages. Plaintiff has filed
a motion to exclude damages testimony relating to U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;5,724,567. The Company has also filed a motion for sanctions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Mediostream, Inc. v. Acer America Corp. et al. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this action against the Company, Acer America
Corp., Dell, Inc. and Gateway, Inc. on August&nbsp;28, 2007 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, Marshall Division, alleging infringement of U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;7,009,655, entitled &#147;Method and System for
Direct Recording of Video Information onto a Disk Medium.&#148; An amended complaint was served on November&nbsp;7, 2007. The amended complaint seeks unspecified damages and other relief. On January&nbsp;25, 2008, the Company filed an answer to the
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">28 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
complaint denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses and also filed a motion to transfer the case to the Northern District of California, which the Court denied.
The Markman hearing is set for August&nbsp;4, 2010 and trial is scheduled for January&nbsp;4, 2011. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Nokia Corporation v.
Apple Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff Nokia Corporation filed this action against the Company on October 22, 2009 in the United States
District Court for the District of Delaware, alleging infringement of U.S. Patent No. 5,802,465, U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;5,862,178, U.S. Patent No. 5,946,651, U.S. Patent No. 6,359,904, U.S. Patent No. 6,694,135, U.S. Patent No.&nbsp;6,755,548, U.S.
Patent No. 6,882,727, U.S. Patent No. 7,009,940, U.S. Patent No. 7,092,672, and U.S. Patent No. 7,403,621. The complaint alleges that these patents are essential to one or more of the GSM, UMTS and 802.11 wireless communications standards, and that
the Company has the right to license these patents from plaintiff on fair, reasonable, and non-discriminatory (&#147;FRAND&#148;) terms and conditions. Plaintiff seeks unspecified FRAND compensation and other relief. The Company&#146;s response to
the complaint is not yet due. The Company intends to defend the case vigorously. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>OPTi Inc. v. Apple Inc. </I></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this action against the Company on January&nbsp;16, 2007 in the United States District Court for the Eastern District of
Texas, Marshall Division, alleging infringement of U.S. Patent Nos. 5,710,906, 5,813,036 and 6,405,291, all entitled &#147;Predictive Snooping of Cache Memory for Master-Initiated Accesses.&#148; The complaint seeks unspecified damages and other
relief. The Company filed an answer on April&nbsp;17, 2007 denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. The Company also asserted counterclaims for declaratory judgment of non-infringement and invalidity. The Markman
hearing took place on November&nbsp;26, 2008 and the Court issued its Markman ruling on December&nbsp;5, 2008. On April&nbsp;3, 2009, the Court ruled that the accused computers sold between 2005 and 2007 infringed the &#146;291 patent. A trial
regarding validity, damages and willfulness commenced on April&nbsp;17, 2009. On April&nbsp;23, 2009, the jury returned a verdict that the patent was valid and willfully infringed, and awarded $19 million in damages. On May&nbsp;1, 2009, plaintiff
filed a motion for entry of judgment, including a request for enhanced damages based on the willfulness finding, seeking a total of $31 million plus attorneys&#146; fees. The Company has opposed that motion and has filed its own motions for judgment
as a matter of law or, alternatively, for a new trial and/or remittitur, on the issues of validity, willfulness and damages. The Court has not entered a judgment and has not set hearing dates for any of the pending motions. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Saito Shigeru Kenchiku Kenkyusho (Shigeru Saito Architecture Institute) v. iPod; Apple Japan Inc. v. Shigeru Saito Architecture Institute
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff&nbsp;Saito filed a petition in the Japan Customs Office in Tokyo on January&nbsp;23, 2007 alleging infringement
by the Company of Japanese&nbsp;Patent No.&nbsp;3852854, entitled &#147;Touch Operation Input Device and Electronic Parts Thereof.&#148; The petition sought an order barring the importation into Japan of fifth generation iPods and second generation
iPod nanos. The Customs Office held a hearing on March&nbsp;22, 2007. The Customs Office rejected the petition to bar importation and dismissed plaintiff&#146;s case. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Apple Japan, Inc. filed a Declaratory Judgment action against Saito on February&nbsp;6, 2007 in the Tokyo District Court, seeking a declaration that the &#145;854 patent is invalid and not infringed.
Saito filed a Counter Complaint for infringement seeking damages. Plaintiff filed a motion to add new accused products into the case, which the Court granted at a hearing on June&nbsp;30, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>St-Germain v. Apple Canada, Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this case in Montreal, Quebec, Canada, on August&nbsp;5, 2005, seeking authorization to institute a class action for the refund by the Company of the Canadian Private Copying Levy that was
applied to the iPod
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">29 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
purchase price in Quebec between December&nbsp;12, 2003 and December&nbsp;14, 2004 but later declared invalid by the Canadian Court. The Company has completed a refund program for this levy. A
class certification hearing took place January&nbsp;13, 2006. On February&nbsp;24, 2006, the Court granted class certification and notice was published during the last week of March 2006. The trial was conducted on October&nbsp;15 and 16, 2007. On
January&nbsp;11, 2008, the Court issued a ruling in plaintiff&#146;s favor. The Court ruled that despite the Company&#146;s good faith efforts with the levy refund program, the Company must pay the amount claimed, and that the class is comprised of
20,000 persons who purchased an iPod in Quebec between December&nbsp;12, 2003 and December&nbsp;14, 2004. The Court ordered the Company to submit a statement of account showing the amount received by the Canadian Private Copying Collective, and the
amount that has already been paid to class members in Quebec under the Company&#146;s levy refund program. The Court also ordered the parties to submit further briefing regarding the collective recovery award by February&nbsp;23, 2008. On
February&nbsp;11, 2008, the Company filed an appeal. A hearing on the appeal is set for October&nbsp;27, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>The Apple
iPod iTunes Antitrust Litigation (formerly Charoensak v. Apple Computer, Inc. and Tucker v. Apple Computer, Inc.); Somers v. Apple Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The first-listed action is a consolidated case combining two cases previously pending under the names <I>Charoensak v. Apple Computer Inc. (formerly Slattery v. Apple Computer Inc.)</I> and <I>Tucker v.
Apple Computer, Inc</I>. The original plaintiff (Slattery) in the Charoensak case filed a purported class action on January&nbsp;3, 2005 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California alleging various claims including
alleged unlawful tying of music purchased on the iTunes Store with the purchase of iPods and unlawful acquisition or maintenance of monopoly market power. Plaintiff&#146;s complaint alleged violations of &#167;&#167;1 and 2 of the Sherman Act (15
U.S.C. &#167;&#167;1 and 2), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;16700 et seq. (the Cartwright Act), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition), common law unjust enrichment and common law
monopolization. Plaintiff sought unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed a motion to dismiss on February&nbsp;10, 2005. On September&nbsp;9, 2005, the Court denied the motion in part and granted it in part. Plaintiff filed an amended
complaint on September&nbsp;23, 2005 and the Company filed an answer on October&nbsp;18, 2005. In August 2006, the Court dismissed Slattery without prejudice and allowed plaintiffs to file an amended complaint naming two new plaintiffs (Charoensak
and Rosen). On November&nbsp;2, 2006, the Company filed an answer to the amended complaint denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Tucker case was filed as a purported class action on July&nbsp;21, 2006 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California alleging various claims including alleged unlawful
tying of music and videos purchased on the iTunes Store with the purchase of iPods and vice versa and unlawful acquisition or maintenance of monopoly market power. The complaint alleges violations of &#167;&#167;1 and 2 of the Sherman Act (15 U.S.C.
&#167;&#167;1 and 2), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;16700 et seq. (the Cartwright Act), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition) and the California Consumer Legal Remedies Act.
Plaintiff sought unspecified damages and other relief. On November&nbsp;3, 2006, the Company filed a motion to dismiss the complaint. On December&nbsp;20, 2006, the Court denied the motion to dismiss. On January&nbsp;11, 2007, the Company filed an
answer denying all material allegations and asserting numerous defenses. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On March&nbsp;20, 2007, the Court consolidated the
two cases. Plaintiffs filed a consolidated complaint on April&nbsp;19, 2007. On June&nbsp;6, 2007, the Company filed an answer to the consolidated complaint denying all material allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. On
July&nbsp;17, 2008, plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification and on October&nbsp;17, 2008, the Company filed its opposition to plaintiffs&#146; motion. The class certification hearing took place on December&nbsp;16, 2008. On
December&nbsp;22, 2008, the Court granted certification of the monopolization claims and denied without prejudice certification of the tying claims pending reconsideration of its denial of the Company&#146;s motion to dismiss. On February&nbsp;13,
2009, the Company filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings as to plaintiffs&#146; tying claims. On May&nbsp;15, 2009, the Court issued an order granting the Company&#146;s motion in part, dismissing the federal per se tying claim and related
state court tying claims and inviting the Company to file another motion for judgment on the pleadings if plaintiffs pursue a rule of reason
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">30 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
tying claim. On July&nbsp;17, 2009, the Court invited the Company to file a motion for reconsideration of the certification of an injunctive-relief class or a motion to strike plaintiffs&#146;
prayer for the type of injunctive relief sought. On August&nbsp;3, 2009, the Company filed a motion for judgment on the pleadings as to the plaintiffs&#146; Rule of Reason tying claim. On August&nbsp;31, 2009, the Company filed a motion seeking
reconsideration and denial of an injunctive relief class. The Company also filed a motion seeking decertification of the Rule 23(b)(3) damages class or alternatively for leave to move for reconsideration. A hearing on the Company&#146;s motion for
judgment on the pleadings as to plaintiffs&#146; Rule of Reason tying claim took place on October&nbsp;5, 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A related
complaint, <I>Somers v. Apple Inc</I>., was filed on December&nbsp;31, 2007 in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California on behalf of a purported class of indirect purchasers, alleging various claims including alleged
unlawful tying of music and videos purchased on the iTunes Store with the purchase of iPods and vice versa and unlawful acquisition or maintenance of monopoly market power. The complaint alleges violations of &#167;&#167;1 and 2 of the Sherman Act
(15 U.S.C. &#167;&#167;1 and 2), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;16700 et seq. (the Cartwright Act), California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition), the California Consumer Legal Remedies Act
and California monopolization law. Plaintiff seeks unspecified damages and other relief. On February&nbsp;21, 2008, the Company filed an answer denying all material allegations and asserting numerous defenses. On February&nbsp;23, 2009, plaintiff
filed a motion for class certification and on April&nbsp;20, 2009, the Company filed its opposition to that motion. An evidentiary hearing on the class certification motion took place on June&nbsp;30, 2009. On July&nbsp;17, 2009, the Court denied
certification of plaintiff&#146;s damage claims and deferred ruling on certification of plaintiff&#146;s injunctive claims pending resolution of the additional briefing requested by the Court, which is described above. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Tse v. Apple Computer, Inc. et al. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff Ho Keung Tse filed this action against the Company and other defendants on August&nbsp;5, 2005 in the United States District Court for the District of Maryland alleging infringement of U.S.
Patent No.&nbsp;6,665,797 entitled &#147;Protection of Software Again [sic] Against Unauthorized Use.&#148; The complaint seeks unspecified damages and other relief. The Company filed an answer on October&nbsp;31, 2005 denying all material
allegations and asserting numerous affirmative defenses. On October&nbsp;28, 2005, the Company and the other defendants filed a motion to transfer the case to the Northern District of California, which was granted on August&nbsp;31, 2006. On
July&nbsp;24, 2007, the Company filed a petition for reexamination of the patent, which the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office granted. On July&nbsp;25, 2007, the Company filed a motion to stay the litigation pending the outcome of the reexamination,
which the Court granted on October&nbsp;4, 2007. On July&nbsp;21, 2009, the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office issued a final Office Action rejecting all asserted claims except for claim 16.&nbsp;On September&nbsp;20, 2009, plaintiff filed a Notice of
Appeal to the Board of Patent Appeals and Interferences from the final Office Action.&nbsp;The Court action remains stayed pending plaintiff&#146;s appeal. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Vitt v. Apple Computer, Inc. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this purported class action
on November&nbsp;7, 2006 in the United States District Court for the Central District of California on behalf of a purported nationwide class of all purchasers of the iBook G4 alleging that the computer&#146;s logic board fails at an abnormally high
rate. The complaint alleges violations of California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17200 (unfair competition) and California Business&nbsp;&amp; Professions Code &#167;17500 (false advertising). Plaintiff seeks unspecified damages and
other relief. The Company filed a motion to dismiss on January&nbsp;19, 2007, which the Court granted on March&nbsp;13, 2007. Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on March&nbsp;26, 2007. The Company filed a motion to dismiss on August&nbsp;16,
2007, which was heard on October&nbsp;4, 2007. The Court has not yet issued a ruling. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Vogel v. Jobs et al. (2006 Action)
</I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiffs filed this purported class action on August&nbsp;24, 2006, in the United States District Court for the Northern
District of California against the Company and certain of the Company&#146;s current and former officers and
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">31 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
directors alleging improper backdating of stock option grants to maximize certain defendants&#146; profits, failing to properly account for those grants and issuing false financial statements. On
January&nbsp;19, 2007, the Court appointed the New York City Employees&#146; Retirement System as lead plaintiff. On March&nbsp;23, 2007, plaintiffs&nbsp;filed a Consolidated Class Action Complaint. The&nbsp;Consolidated&nbsp;Complaint purports to
be brought on behalf of several classes of holders of the Company&#146;s stock and&nbsp;asserts claims under Section&nbsp;14(a) and 20(a) of the Exchange Act&nbsp;as well as state law. The Consolidated Complaint seeks rescission of amendments to
various stock option and other incentive compensation plans, an accounting and damages in an unspecified amount. Defendants filed a motion to dismiss on June&nbsp;8, 2007, which was heard on September&nbsp;7, 2007. On November&nbsp;14, 2007, the
Court issued an order dismissing all securities claims with prejudice, and held that any amended complaint could only be styled as a derivative case. On December&nbsp;14, 2007, plaintiff filed a motion for leave to file a first amended consolidated
class action complaint. On January&nbsp;23, 2008, defendants filed an opposition to plaintiff&#146;s motion. Plaintiff&#146;s motion was heard on March&nbsp;21, 2008. On May&nbsp;14, 2008, the Court issued an order denying plaintiffs&#146; motion
for leave to amend. The court entered judgment dismissing the case on June&nbsp;12, 2008. On June&nbsp;17, 2008, plaintiffs filed a notice of appeal. A hearing on plaintiffs&#146; appeal took place on October&nbsp;7, 2009. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Vogel v. Apple Inc., et al. (2008 Action) </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Plaintiff filed this purported class action on June&nbsp;27, 2008, in the United States District Court for the Northern District of California against the Company and certain of the Company&#146;s current
and former officers and directors. The allegations, which arise out of the Company&#146;s past stock option practices, are similar to those in the 2006 <I>Vogel v. Jobs et al. </I>action that was dismissed on June&nbsp;12, 2008, as described above.
The complaint purports to be brought on behalf of several classes of holders of the Company&#146;s stock and asserts claims under Sections 10(b) and 20(a) of the Exchange Act. The complaint seeks rescission of amendments to various stock option and
other incentive compensation plans, an accounting and damages in an unspecified amount. On July&nbsp;22, 2008, the Court stayed this case pending the appeal in the 2006 Action. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:18px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;4.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">None. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">32 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">
<h5 align="left"><a href="#toc">Table of Contents</a></h5>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>PART II </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="9%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;5.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Market for Registrant&#146;s Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s common stock is traded on the over-the-counter market and is quoted on the NASDAQ Global Select Market under the symbol
AAPL and on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange under the symbol APCD. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Price Range of Common Stock </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The price range per share of common stock presented below represents the highest and lowest sales prices for the Company&#146;s common stock
on the NASDAQ Global Select Market during each quarter of the two most recent years. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Company Stock Performance </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px"
ALIGN="justify"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following graph shows a five-year comparison of cumulative total shareholder return, calculated on a dividend reinvested basis, for the Company, the S&amp;P 500 Composite Index
and the S&amp;P Computer Hardware Index. The graph assumes $100 was invested in each of the Company&#146;s common stock, the S&amp;P 500 Composite Index, and the S&amp;P Computer Hardware Index on September&nbsp;30, 2004. Data points on the graph
are annual. Note that historic stock price performance is not necessarily indicative of future stock price performance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center">
